Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Examining Upper Mantle Volatile History Through Isotopic Variations of Carbon, Nitrogen, Hydrogen and Noble Gases in Undegassed Mid-Ocean Ridge Basalts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Measurements of volatiles such as carbon dioxide, water, nitrogen and noble gases in submarine basalts from mid-ocean ridges have provided considerable insight into the origin of Earth's atmosphere and oceans, and the geologic history of cycling between the surface of the Earth and its interior. However, almost all submarine basalts have lost much of their volatile inventory by degassing when they are erupted, which has led to a major loss of the reliable chemical data needed to identify pristine chemical signatures from Earth's mantle. As a result, there is significant uncertainty and controversy in our understanding of the origins of volatiles and their fluxes into and out of the Earth. This research carries out analyses of the very rare occurrences of undegassed mid-ocean ridge basalts to obtain information on the mantle isotopic composition of carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen and noble gases (helium, neon and argon). Collectively, these gases can be used synergistically to better understand how Earth's atmosphere and oceans formed and evolved. Mid-ocean ridges are fundamental geologic features of Earth's surface, and one of the most intriguing challenges in geosciences is understanding the processes by which they are created and evolve. The chemical and isotopic data resulting from this project are fundamental in this regard, and will provide benchmarks for years to come for models of degassing at ocean ridges and the origin and evolution of Earth's volatiles. Broader impacts of the work include funding an institution in Oklahoma, a state that receives comparatively little federal money (i.e., an EPSCoR state) and the development of new international collaborations with French scientists. It also uses NSF-funded analytical facilities at Oregon State University and develops new methods for analyzing noble gases in rock samples, building infrastructure for science. Findings will also be incorporated into classes taught by the investigators and used to develop a new seminar for graduate students centered on modeling of reservoirs, processes and fluxes in chemical geodynamics.

The scientific goals of this research are to test the extent to which regions of the upper mantle beneath mid-ocean ridges and continental rifts are similar in their volatile abundances and isotopic compositions on a global scale. Analyses of carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, and noble gases in undegassed mid-ocean ridge basalts will allow, for the first time, testing of the inter-relationships of noble gas and major volatile isotopes in CO2, N2, and H2O without employing degassing corrections. This allows a direct test for regional heterogeneity in the upper mantle. The research also specifically addresses the questions: (1) What proportions of the volatiles C, N and H2O in the upper mantle are primordial versus recycled; (2) do carbon stable isotopes in the ultra-depleted mid-ocean ridge basalts carry a record of earlier depletion in low degree melts that appears to be required in formation of the ultra-depleted source; (3) what is the behavior and concentration of N in the depleted upper mantle; and (4) what record of early Earth processes is preserved in the primordial isotope ratios of upper mantle noble gases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated submarine lavas erupted along the global mid-ocean ridge system. The rims of the lavas are quenched to glass during eruption due to the overlying water pressure. Commonly, this basaltic glass contains small bubbles (vesicles) formed as carbon dioxide exsolves from the melt during magma ascent and decompression. We investigated rare cases of basalt glass that started with low CO2 contents and so never formed bubbles. Their CO2 concentrations dissolved in the glass are below saturation at the respective collection depths. These rare occurrences of volatile-undersaturated basalts allow a direct probe of the chemical make-up of volatiles in Earth?s mantle, because the basalts ascended from their mantle source region without gas loss effects that complicate interpretation of the varying concentrations. These basalts are also highly depleted in key trace elements, such as barium (Ba) and niobium (Nb), that are often used to probe the chemical composition and partial melting of the mantle. The undersaturated, non-degassed mid-ocean ridge basalts (MORBs) can be used to obtain information on the state of volatile species such as carbon, hydrogen and helium in the mantle.

Coupled variations of carbon and helium in a global suite of thirteen undersaturated MORBs reveal that helium behaves as the element that is most incompatible in crystal structures of minerals during mantle melting, resulting in helium being highly concentrated in the melt relative to the solid mantle. This extreme incompatibility of helium stems both from its small atomic size, its charge neutrality, and its enhanced mobility by diffusion relative to other chemical species in the mantle during its partial melting.

A detailed study from the Garrett Transform Fault (GTF) and the southern East Pacific Rise (EPR) revealed an intriguing offset in the helium isotope composition for basalts within the transform domain compared to the nearby EPR (see Figure 1). Higher helium isotope ratios (3He/4He) in the transform domain are associated with greater trace element depletion. This allows a further test for the origin of volatile undersaturated basalts using CO2/Ba and CO2/Nb ratios. CO2 is highly correlated with Ba and Nb in basalts from the transform domain (14 basalts total, including 5 undersaturated basalts).  These basalts originated by partial melting of chemically heterogeneous mantle that was variably depleted in incompatible elements by prior melting. Their CO2/Ba and CO2/Nb ratios of 104 and 303, respectively, are indistinguishable from ratios determined in earlier global studies (Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific) of undersaturated MORBs. The ridge and transform domains have distinct 3He/4He due to partial melting beneath the GTF of mantle that originally contained a small fraction (≤5%) of ancient, chemically enriched heterogeneities. These heterogeneities are more readily melted than the depleted ambient mantle, and they were stripped from the GTF mantle by prior melting beneath the EPR. This model explains the 3He/4He distinction between transform and spreading ridge domains if the heterogeneities were enriched in uranium (U) and thorium (Th) and had low 3He/4He (due to the production of 4He by U and Th radioactive decay), as would occur in material recycled to the Earth?s interior by plate tectonics. The enriched mantle has CO2/3He of 2x109, the same ratio ascribed to the upper mantle source for basalts elsewhere along the global mid-ocean ridge system. In contrast, the ultra-depleted mantle sampled by basalts in the Garrett transform domain has CO2/3He of 3x108 or less. Because 3He is a primordial species that has been trapped within the Earth since it formation, the higher CO2/3He in EPR basalts shows that most of the carbon in Earth?s mantle beneath mid-ocean ridges has been recycled by plate tectonics.

CO2 concentrations in basalts from the 2005-06 eruption on the EPR at 9?50?N indicate closed-system degassing (no bubble loss) during ascent from their last depth of equilibration at 1.4-1.8 km below seafloor, similar to that of seismically imaged magma lenses in the area. There is a large fractionation between He and CO2 trapped in the bubbles compared to equilibrium predictions, due to the much slower diffusion in the melt of carbon relative to helium. CO2/Ba ratios and the C isotope composition of lavas compared to vent fluids indicate earlier stages of open-system degassing, when ≥50% of the initial CO2 was lost. This makes estimates for the mantle C isotope composition beneath this part of the EPR uncertain and model dependent.

 

The project supported undergraduate students at The University of Tulsa, thereby helping to improve the research competitiveness of Oklahoma, a National Science Foundation EPSCoR state.
